some are very good and have this in all in an automated fashion some are not there are some places um in

from there to um build a uh to of come up with a comprehensive data
set of how we um pull this together um but this is completely indicative of most
public open data the vast majority of public open data is
unstructured stale and unlicensed so it's it's typically locked um
in a pdf somewhere typically not even in a machine readable pdf but something
that's been scanned and converted into a pdf stale so typically when governments
produce open data portals they take this data and they um stick it up there and then they forget about it so there's
no process to up update this data and uh
and more often than not um unlicensed and licensing is a really big deal especially for people like um google you
know people can and will sue us so it's very important for us to be able to know that we can
um use the data in the way it's intended and if if there isn't a license there for us to
use um then there's very little we can do um so to get ourselves out of this mess
what we did is we um we founded a nonprofit called the voting information project
and we funded that and this project they started out by trying to gather together as much of
this data themselves by basically emailing reaching out to the elections officials
in every um state city and precinct across the u.s collating that together into
a big list and then going through and manually correcting it by hand a lot of the initial work was um

um up to the uh 2008 elections uh and we also defined a standard like
this we defined an xml standard the machine readable standard so that this voting information project
could act as a hub basically the one true source that aggregates together
and removes a lot of the problems that we saw with this data so it ends up in a format that is structured
that is uh has uh refreshed reliable intervals um and is um um
uh licensed uh and this is funded not only by um volunteers but also um google and now
a number of other foundations um give money to this um
nonprofit to keep this government data up to date um and uh we aggregate that data
together we pull it into google and that lets us build these technologies on top of it which for example tell you that you can vote

data through apis to let other people um build on top of it my favorite example

you want to attempt to build anything using data that is apparently open so even when data is open
it is often moving that into a um

we decided that this was back when i was working in europe the engineers there decided that

time to put public transport into google maps and we naively went to all

um negotiations with them they would say well okay but you have to display it in
exactly the way that we display it on our site no changes and we won't give you the data you will have to call out to our services
and and pull that data in which is just totally impractical for for building a project like um google
maps um so then we played the other approach and we went to the second tier cities and we went to um places like in the uk
manchester kind of up-and-coming cities and said hey do you want to out-innovate london if you want to
out-innovate london you want to kind of um show that you're uh that you're really an up-and-coming city
would you partner with us and and share your transit data with us and so we um we started talking to these
cities and we drafted a specification called
at the time it was called the google transit feed specification gtfs since now the general feed transit feed
specification and we got a couple of initial partners i can't even remember who the first
panel was i think it was german somebody in germany munich maybe we got them to start sharing data with
us in this open standard and at the same time they would publish that open
standard on their own websites too and gradually gradually gradually over the course of about five or six
years we were able to to pick off the um other cities too um and move up to
the kind of the uh secondary cities and lots of different countries and then eventually get to the point where
we could go back to people like paris london and new york and say you know you're looking pretty
embarrassing now because i can search for public transit everywhere except your city isn't this a bit um silly and eventually
they relented and they started publishing data in in these formats too um and i think the
lesson there is that the uh uh you know it is actually possible both in terms of voter information
projects uh and gtfs to go from a world where you have
very very stale unlicensed difficult to use data and eventually
gradually move people to a world where the the data is machine readable and
available for everybody to use and i think actually that you know more important than um the uh transit directions in google
maps has been an explosion in recent years of very very specific transit uh applications especially on

a whole ecosystem of these products which is exactly the kind of thing that we want to do
so it took a long time to build consensus and i think one of the key um lessons here is that the the
driving force of this was actually being able to build a product that people loved and cared about it was much
easier for us to when we went into these negotiations to say you know we have x hundred million

the open data ecosystem because we managed to drag or help drag
um the the data standards for these two domains forward because we had a compelling product

of this data unlicensed stale pdfs um in the name of transparency really
